speaker: Dan
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English– the show that brings you an interesting topic, authentic listening practice and six items of incredibly useful vocabulary. I'm Dan…

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil. Now, a favourite topic today: food, and how food can influence your mood. Dan, tell me, what food makes you happy?

speaker: Dan
text: Oh, you know, ice cream, chocolate… chocolate always puts a smile on my face.

speaker: Neil
text: And a few inches round your waistline! Sadly, the research we’ll be looking at today doesn’t suggest you eat more chocolate… but it does talk about bacteria!

speaker: Dan
text: Bacteria – those simple, small organisms – they make me happy?

speaker: Neil
text: Absolutely, the so-called ‘good’ bacteria do! We’ll get to that, but first we’ll look at today’s question. How many bacteria are there in the human body?

speaker: Neil
text: a) 39 million

speaker: Neil
text: b) 39 billion

speaker: Neil
text: c) 39 trillion

speaker: Dan
text: They are pretty small. I’m going to go for c) 39 trillion.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, we’ll find out if you’re right… by counting them one by one.

speaker: Dan
text: That’s going to take longer than six minutes!

speaker: gut
text: Yes it is, so let’s get moving! Scientists believe your mental state is connected to the bacteria in your gut.

speaker: gut
text: My gut - my stomach and the other organs my food passes through…

speaker: anxiety
text: Yes. Researchers at McMaster University in Canada and University College Cork in Ireland have found that certain bacteria help reduce anxiety in mice…

speaker: Anxiety
text: Anxiety – the state of being worried or anxious. I don’t like the sound of an anxious mouse.

speaker: germ
text: Well I’m afraid there’s another mouse experiment coming up. Researchers at Kyushu University found germ-free mice showed more stress…

speaker: Germsgerms
text: Germs – a general word for bacteria and microorganisms, usually the ones which cause disease… So germs help reduce stress and anxiety in mice. Any research on humans?

speaker: Neil
text: The BBC TV programme Trust me, I’m a Doctor has just explored this. They looked at foods which are high in ‘good’ bacteria – a claim which more and more food products are making these days.

speaker: Dan
text: Yes, it’s a phrase that appears a lot in marketing.

speaker: fermented
text: But many traditional foods are high in good bacteria as well. They found that homemade fermented food was best.

speaker: fermented
text: So things like miso soup, kimchi, yoghurt, sauerkraut – all these are fermented. Have you tried all of those?

speaker: Neil
text: I love miso soup and kimchi. And fermentation is the process where sugars in food are turned into acids and alcohol.

speaker: Fermented foodsgut
text: Fermented foods are full of lots of good bacteria for your gut… Anything else from the BBC programme?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, this is the man behind the BBC study, Dr Michael Mosley. In this clip, a radio presenter asks him about the best kind of food to make us happy.

speaker: Presenter
text: What’s the good mood food? What shall we eat now to cheer ourselves up?

speaker: diet
text: Mediterranean diet. Olive oil; oily fish, full of omega 3, which is really good for the brain; whole grains; lots of fruits and vegetables. Sugar: terrible for you.

speaker: Presenter
text: Not chocolate eclairs then?

speaker: Dr Michael Mosley
text: Sadly not. That will make you feel good for about 30 seconds until you finish it and then you feel terribly guilty.

speaker: Presenter
text: Right, ok. Mediterranean it is.

speaker: dietdiet
text: He said the best kind of food is the Mediterranean diet. Now, a diet can mean 'an eating plan designed to help you lose weight'.

speaker: Neil
text: But that’s not what it means here. Here it refers to the food and drink eaten by a group of people – in this case, the people living around the Mediterranean Sea.

speaker: fermented
text: Lots of oily fish, olive oil, grains, fruits and vegetables. And of course, add in plenty of fermented food too.

speaker: not rocket science
text: And don’t eat too many fatty, sugary, chocolaty things like chocolate eclairs – those are buns filled with cream and covered in chocolate. It’s really not rocket science, is it?

speaker: not rocket science
text: Eating healthily is pretty straightforward, even if the science behind it is complex. When you say something is not rocket science, you mean 'it’s not difficult to understand'.

speaker: Neil
text: Now, are you ready for some counting?

speaker: Dan
text: Ah yes, you wanted me to count all the bacteria in my body! I said 39 trillion.

speaker: Neil
text: And you were right. The number goes up and down, but on average we’re thought to have around 39 trillion bacterial cells in the body, according to the Weizmann Institute in Israel. The interesting thing is they think that there are only 30 trillion human cells in the body.

speaker: Dan
text: So there’s more bacteria than human in me?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, maybe just you, Dan! Now, before the bacteria take over completely, let’s look over today’s words one more time.

speaker: Gutguts
text: Gut was first. It means 'the stomach and other organs which digest our food'. But here’s an extra tip - the word can also mean ‘bravery’ when used in the plural. You’ve got guts, Neil, wearing that crazy shirt in this office!

speaker: anxietyAnxiety
text: Why thank you. Maybe I don’t feel any anxiety about how I look! Anxiety was our second word, and it means 'fear or worry'. The adjective is anxious.

speaker: Germsgerms
text: You know what makes me anxious? Germs. I wash my hands fifty times a day. I can’t stand the idea of getting ill from all the germs around here.

speaker: germsgerms
text: Yes, germs are tiny organisms, and usually refers to those which carry disease. But as we heard, certain germs are good for you!

speaker: fermented
text: Especially those which are in fermented food. That’s food which has gone through a process where sugars turn into acids and alcohol. They often taste sour or bitter.

speaker: fermentingfermented
text: We also talk about fermenting alcoholic drinks. Beer and wine are fermented.

speaker: dietdietdiet
text: Does that mean I should make them a part of my diet? A diet not only means 'a healthy eating plan', but can also mean 'the foods and drinks consumed by an individual or group'. Which country has the best diet, Neil?

speaker: dietfermented
text: Well, in my opinion the Japanese diet. It’s my favourite anyway – very varied and plenty of fermented food!

speaker: it’s not rocket science
text: And finally we had – it’s not rocket science – it’s simple to understand. An example?

speaker: isn’t rocket science
text: Brewing beer isn’t rocket science – you just need hops, yeast and patience.

speaker: Dan
text: And there we are – a rocket speed review of today’s words! And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon.

speaker: Neil
text: And we are on social media too. Make sure to visit us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube.

speaker: Both
text: Bye!
